I finished this lecture on Sep. 16, 2022, at 22:35pm. Thank you Prof. Strang, the last month (Aug. 7 - Sep. 16) was so wonderful, memorable.
I love the moment when the prof spotted the solution 3, 3, 4 and exclaimed “it works!”. Eureka!

I suppose that’s why MIT is not for every student and why it is difficult and costly to get into. This course review requires a special level of mastery of the material, which assumes a great deal of understanding and problem practice throughout the course. When a matrix is not square and doesn’t have a unique solution (independent rows or columns) all kinds of scenarios could happen. Adding to that, whether the matrix is orthogonal, orthonormal, symmetric, positive or semi definite, as well as others involving Eigenvectors, values, pivots and determinants. I suppose that the best way to wrap all that information around the head is to start with some simple 2 by 2 or 3 by 3 matrix and experiment with all different scenarios using a good software package to spit out the output and see how the theory works. I am using scientific notebook.
Thank you Professor Strang Thank you MIT OCW 2022/08/07

what an epic!!!

I finally completed this amazing course today on 08/06/2022, it took 34 days to complete and it was totally worth it. I watched all lectures, read all lecture summaries, recitation videos solved each problem set and exams. Thanks to Professor Strang, the lectures were not difficult to understand, the hard part was doing them neatly and regularly. Thank you Professor Strang for this amazing course !!!

Today I have completed the course; actually, I cannot be more proud to take this course and understand linear Algebra more than Any course that my uni gave me. Reckon that I am doing my masters in CS, and this basically is the key to everything since my uni bachelors failed to offer me reasonable mathematics courses. I was never good at any major of mathematics, but right now, I feel I can rock any exam with the highest grade and enjoy studying for it. The biggest takeaway from this class, besides how to guess the vector that makes the equations equal, is how to do math. Out of all of my math teachers, only Prof. Strang taught me this.

I am so thankful that courses like these are open to public viewing, as I was able to complete the course lectures, learning this invaluable math. Now I feel more prepared and ready to tackle this next course.

Thank you so much, dear Professor Strang, all TA's, the camera personnel, and all other supporting staff. Started learning this course about ten years ago. Will go through the exercise, problems, and exams also, all necessary steps to refresh memories and memorize essential details. Will continue to finish  Professor Strang's Highlights of Calculus, differential equation, and three other linear algebra courses. You are a blessing to humanity, Professor. @ElectricTeaCup  actually i want to pursue msc in data science and for that linear algebra is necessary as i am not good at maths i want to start from begginers level so can you tell me what are plthe prerequisites for linera alg. Cuz some says calculus is required and some says knowledge of algebra 1 and 2 is required so can you please filter which prerequisites topics are directly related to linear algebra or this particular course 🙏

@callxaditya  The requirements are high school mathematics. Finish Serge Lange's basic mathematics and you should be good (that's what I did at least). For everything else, google and pick up along the way. Good luck!

What are  the prerequisites in order to take this course ?
I just passed out standard 10th , now i am in standard 11th. School has not started yet . Please guide. Can i take this course ?
@theworkethic263  No you can't
@vedantparanjape  Why ?
@vedantparanjape  will I have to complete whole 11th and 12 th standard maths ?
@vedantparanjape  Please elaborate
@vedantparanjape  Are you from India?

@theworkethic263  If you already have differential calculus you are good, if not, you need to the bare minimum concurrently take that course.  If you are a highly motivated student and ready to invest the time and hard work, you need to know in advance the algebra of lines, planes and vectors in 3 dimensions, concept of determinants, how to solve systems of linear equations For the applications he covers, you need to concurrently watch as well  introductory videos about them:  Markov chains, Fourier analysis, spring-mass system stability, etc, otherwise it could be frustrating

The prerequisites listed on the course are: "18.02 Multivariable Calculus is a formal prerequisite for MIT students wishing to enroll in 18.06 Linear Algebra, but knowledge of calculus is not required to learn the subject.  To succeed in this course you will need to be comfortable with vectors, matrices, and three-dimensional coordinate systems. This material is presented in the first few lectures of 18.02 Multivariable Calculus, and again here.  The basic operations of linear algebra are those you learned in grade school...". So if you already know some multivariable calculus this could be a first year course. See the course on MIT OpenCourseWare for more details at http://ocw.mit.edu/18-06S05.

You're a bit confused. He teaches 34 sections of 18.06, staggered so that each one starts the day after the last, and about 45 minutes later. This was just one continuous 24 hour period of teaching with the order reversed for our convenience. It's more efficient that way; just the kind of innovation we expect from MIT.

I am a physics student myself (Engineering Physics), and I have always thought that the best lectures are those where every part of a course is described in detail. Instead of just presenting formulas - like a lot of professors love to do for some reason - everything should be explained in such a clear way that it will feel obvious and natural after the lecture - preferably to such a degree that you will be able to derive the formulas and reasonings yourself. Also, I believe that proofs and similar formalities should be kept to a minimum until the subject has been presented with a bunch of examples, because I think that examples and questions from old exams are the best ways to make things as clear as possible, because this lets you see each step in many different types of problems while working through actual problems at the same time.

+Laurelindo The problem with examples is, although they can give you a better sense, they can almost never prove a theorem. A clear distinction should be made between intuition and proof of a claim, distinctions between assumptions, suspicions, and derivations.

By the way, youtube is for some reason changing the "less than" sign into "<". Following up on my last comment (this feels like "linear algebra 500 characters at a time!"), if the solution is not unique there are either no solutions or infinitely many. Since we know that b=[1, 0, 0] has no solution in Ax=b, it must mean it's the former case. To answer this question means reversing the reasoning here. Starting with the fact that b has no solution and deducing from there that r is less than m.

It's a little more into matrix theory than that. He's assuming that we've already done the elimination process, and if there were any repeated equation while eliminating, it would yield an entire row of just 0's -that is, no pivot. So in essence saying that there's no pivot in one of the columns is the same as saying that one of the equations was repeated. The rank, r, is the number of pivots, m the number of rows. So if r<m, there must be a column without pivots, and the solution is not unique.
